lines.text: Enter Nurse

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: Mistress! what, mistress! Juliet! fast, I warrant her, she: Why, lamb! why, lady! fie, you slugabed! Why, love, I say! madam! sweetheart! why, bride! What, not a word you take your pennyworths now Sleep for a week for the next night, I warrant, The County Paris hath set up his rest, That you shall rest but little. God forgive me, Marry, and amen, how sound is she asleep! I must needs wake her. Madam, madam, madam! Ay, let the county take you in your bed Hell fright you up, i faith. Will it not be What, dressd! and in your clothes! and down again! I must needs wake you Lady! lady! lady! Alas, alas! Help, help! my ladys dead! O, welladay, that ever I was born! Some aqua vitae, ho! My lord! my lady!
Undraws the curtains
Enter LADY CAPULET

lines.speaker: lady capulet
lines.text: What noise is here

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: O lamentable day!

lines.speaker: lady capulet
lines.text: What is the matter

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: Look, look! O heavy day!

lines.speaker: lady capulet
lines.text: O me, O me! My child, my only life, Revive, look up, or I will die with thee! Help, help! Call help.
Enter CAPULET

lines.speaker: capulet
lines.text: For shame, bring Juliet forth her lord is come.

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: Shes dead, deceased, shes dead alack the day!

lines.speaker: lady capulet
lines.text: Alack the day, shes dead, shes dead, shes dead!

lines.speaker: capulet
lines.text: Ha! let me see her: out, alas! shes cold: Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff Life and these lips have long been separated: Death lies on her like an untimely frost Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: O lamentable day!

lines.speaker: lady capulet
lines.text: O woful time!

lines.speaker: capulet
lines.text: Death, that hath taen her hence to make me wail, Ties up my tongue, and will not let me speak.
Enter FRIAR LAURENCE and PARIS, with Musicians

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: Come, is the bride ready to go to church

lines.speaker: capulet
lines.text: Ready to go, but never to return. O son! the night before thy weddingday Hath Death lain with thy wife. There she lies, Flower as she was, deflowered by him. Death is my soninlaw, Death is my heir My daughter he hath wedded: I will die, And leave him all life, living, all is Deaths.

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Have I thought long to see this mornings face, And doth it give me such a sight as this

lines.speaker: lady capulet
lines.text: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day! Most miserable hour that eer time saw In lasting labour of his pilgrimage! But one, poor one, one poor and loving child, But one thing to rejoice and solace in, And cruel death hath catchd it from my sight!

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: O woe! O woful, woful, woful day! Most lamentable day, most woful day, That ever, ever, I did yet behold! O day! O day! O day! O hateful day! Never was seen so black a day as this: O woful day, O woful day!

lines.speaker: paris
lines.text: Beguiled, divorced, wronged, spited, slain! Most detestable death, by thee beguild, By cruel cruel thee quite overthrown! O love! O life! not life, but love in death!

lines.speaker: capulet
lines.text: Despised, distressed, hated, martyrd, killd! Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now To murder, murder our solemnity O child! O child! my soul, and not my child! Dead art thou! Alack! my child is dead And with my child my joys are buried.

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: Peace, ho, for shame! confusions cure lives not In these confusions. Heaven and yourself Had part in this fair maid now heaven hath all, And all the better is it for the maid: Your part in her you could not keep from death, But heaven keeps his part in eternal life. The most you sought was her promotion For twas your heaven she should be advanced: And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself O, in this love, you love your child so ill, That you run mad, seeing that she is well: Shes not well married that lives married long But shes best married that dies married young. Dry up your tears, and stick your rosemary On this fair corse and, as the custom is, In all her best array bear her to church: For though fond nature bids us an lament, Yet natures tears are reasons merriment.

lines.speaker: capulet
lines.text: All things that we ordained festival, Turn from their office to black funeral Our instruments to melancholy bells, Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast, Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change, Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse, And all things change them to the contrary.

lines.speaker: friar laurence
lines.text: Sir, go you in and, madam, go with him And go, Sir Paris every one prepare To follow this fair corse unto her grave: The heavens do lour upon you for some ill Move them no more by crossing their high will.
Exeunt CAPULET, LADY CAPULET, PARIS, and FRIAR LAURENCE

lines.speaker: first musician
lines.text: Faith, we may put up our pipes, and be gone.

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: Honest goodfellows, ah, put up, put up For, well you know, this is a pitiful case.
Exit

lines.speaker: first musician
lines.text: Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.
Enter PETER

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: Musicians, O, musicians, Hearts ease, Hearts ease: O, an you will have me live, play Hearts ease.

lines.speaker: first musician
lines.text: Why Hearts ease

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: O, musicians, because my heart itself plays My heart is full of woe: O, play me some merry dump, to comfort me.

lines.speaker: first musician
lines.text: Not a dump we tis no time to play now.

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: You will not, then

lines.speaker: first musician
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: I will then give it you soundly.

lines.speaker: first musician
lines.text: What will you give us

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: No money, on my faith, but the gleek I will give you the minstrel.

lines.speaker: first musician
lines.text: Then I will give you the servingcreature.

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: Then will I lay the servingcreatures dagger on your pate. I will carry no crotchets: Ill re you, Ill fa you do you note me

lines.speaker: first musician
lines.text: An you re us and fa us, you note us.

lines.speaker: second musician
lines.text: Pray you, put up your dagger, and put out your wit.

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: Then have at you with my wit! I will drybeat you with an iron wit, and put up my iron dagger. Answer me like men: When griping grief the heart doth wound, And doleful dumps the mind oppress, Then music with her silver sound why silver sound why music with her silver sound What say you, Simon Catling

lines.speaker: musician
lines.text: Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: Pretty! What say you, Hugh Rebeck

lines.speaker: second musician
lines.text: I say silver sound, because musicians sound for silver.

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: Pretty too! What say you, James Soundpost

lines.speaker: third musician
lines.text: Faith, I know not what to say.

lines.speaker: peter
lines.text: O, I cry you mercy you are the singer: I will say for you. It is music with her silver sound, because musicians have no gold for sounding: Then music with her silver sound With speedy help doth lend redress.
Exit

lines.speaker: first musician
lines.text: What a pestilent knave is this same!

lines.speaker: second musician
lines.text: Hang him, Jack! Come, well in here tarry for the mourners, and stay dinner.
Exeunt
